I've been thinking about an odd twist on the notion of slice category. Let CCC be a category, and define S(C,c)\mathscr{S}(C,c)S(C,c)
objects: (P↣C(−,c),a∈C)(P \rightarrowtail C(-,c), a\in C)(P↣C(−,c),a∈C) -- a sieve on ccc and an object (thought of as P(a)⊂C(a,c)P(a)\subset C(a,c)P(a)⊂C(a,c))
homsets: [(P,a)→(Q,b)]={u:b→a  ∣  ∀f∈P(a).  f(u)∈Q(b)}[(P,a)\to (Q,b)] = \{u:b\to a \; | \; \forall f\in P(a). \; f(u)\in Q(b) \}[(P,a)→(Q,b)]={u:b→a∣∀f∈P(a).f(u)∈Q(b)}
with ordinary composition and identity.
I'm thinking of sieves as types, in order to get something like a "category of types and terms" in the "kind context" ccc.
There are some decisions in this construction that are flexible. Right now I'm searching for good reasons for the decisions, and how to describe this construction as canonical.
I know that it involves the Yoneda embedding of CCC, composed with the subobject functor -- and somehow combining this process with the Grothendieck construction.
If anyone has ideas, let me know. I'll post on here when there's progress.

On the type theory side, the construction is unusual. In the semantics of polymorphic type theories, one has an indexed category F:C→CatF:C\to \mathrm{Cat}F:C→Cat where F(c)F(c)F(c) is the category of types and terms in the kind context ccc.
But a morphism in this category of types and terms is a judgement of the form c  ∣  x:P⊢o(x):Qc \; | \; x:P \vdash o(x):Qc∣x:P⊢o(x):Q for some constructor ooo.
So one thing that's odd about the construction above, besides the contravariance, is that morphisms are inputs rather than operations.

A way to construct that could be this: consider the functor from a site C→Cat\bf{C}\to \bf{Cat}C→Cat sending an object to the category of sieves on that object (it occurs now to me this should be just Sub∘y\rm{Sub} \circ ySub∘y, where yyy is good ol' Yoneda embedding). Then let Grothendieck do its thing, and you get a category where

  • objects are pairs (sieves on AAA, a sieve on AAA)
  • morphisms are images of morphisms of sieves preserving the given sieve, which should be what you proposed as homset

Now this category should be the same as yours if you realize having an object of C\bf{C}C and having the set of sieves on a given object is the same thing: just take the maximal sieve to recover your object.

So here's the situation. As you've observed, for any Grothendieck site (C,J)(\mathcal{C},J)(C,J) we have a pseudofunctor from any category Cop\mathcal{C}^{\mathrm{op}}Cop into Cat\mathrm{Cat}Cat sending each object of C\mathcal{C}C to the poset of covering sieves over it and each morphism fff to the mapping which pulls sieves back along fff; this is well-defined thanks to the stability axiom for G' topologies. Applying the Grothendieck construction we get a fibration ∫P→C\int\mathcal{P} \to \mathcal{C}∫P→C which has a right adjoint, this time thanks to the maximality axiom for G' topologies. Applying Yoneda, we get an adjoint pair of essential geometric morphisms between PSh(∫P)\mathrm{PSh}(\int\mathcal{P})PSh(∫P) and PSh(C)\mathrm{PSh}(\mathcal{C})PSh(C):
fibrationadjunction.png

The fact that an intersection of covering sieves is a covering sieve means that the colimits defining the left-most adjoint in this situation are filtered, so this functor preserves finite limits. That is, we have a diagram of geometric morphisms of the kind that I asked about very recently. Note also that F∗F^*F∗ and Ranm\mathrm{Ran}_mRanm​ are full and faithful, so the upward morphisms are geometric inclusions. These geometric morphisms contain all of the information we from the Grothendieck topology, in the sense that:

  • LanF∘Ranm\mathrm{Lan}_F \circ \mathrm{Ran}_mLanF​∘Ranm​ is precisely the plus construction(!!!!)
  • The 2-equalizer of the upward geometric morphisms, or equivalently the 2-pullback of one against the other, is precisely the subtopos of JJJ-sheaves on C\mathcal{C}C.

This establishes a special case of the fact that geometric inclusions of toposes are regular monomorphisms, but also begs the question of whether some of the general properties of the plus construction (such as idempotence) are true for general situations of this form. One is also led to wonder whether this can be generalised to give a "universal property" characterisation of geometric inclusions in the 2-category of toposes and geometric morphisms. Finally, iirc the properties of fibrations are inherited (weakly) by LanF\mathrm{Lan}_FLanF​, so we wonder if this can be transformed can be expressed concisely in a 2-categorical way. These are just some of the loose ends I mentioned.

Morgan Rogers said:

But... where did your S(C,c) come from?

Yeah, so I should explain my motivation for this construction.

I'm taking CCC to be some kind of algebraic theory. Take the theory of monoids Th.Mon\mathrm{Th.Mon}Th.Mon. A sieve in a theory represents a "form" which represents a subset of terms you can make in the language.

For example, the operation m:2→1m:2\to 1m:2→1 generates the sieve
S(m)={o:n→1  ∣  ∃⟨t1,t2⟩:n→2.  o=m(t1,t2)}S(m)=\{o:n\to 1 \; | \; \exists \langle t_1,t_2 \rangle: n\to 2. \; o=m(t_1,t_2)\}S(m)={o:n→1∣∃⟨t1​,t2​⟩:n→2.o=m(t1​,t2​)}
-- the class of all terms which are the product of two terms.
The sieves generated by the theory are like "base types", and various constructions in the presheaf topos are like type constructors.
Turns out you can get quite a lot from this idea -- from an algebraic theory you can get a polymorphic type theory, with subtyping, recursion, and lots of nice things.

Of course for very simple theories like Th.Mon\mathrm{Th.Mon}Th.Mon, it's not the most useful thing until you map this onto models. A type such as
prime:=¬[e]∧¬[m(¬[e],¬[e])]\mathrm{prime} := eg [e] \wedge eg[m( eg[e], eg[e])]prime:=¬[e]∧¬[m(¬[e],¬[e])] is empty, because there aren't any concrete elements.
so, one sec

Alright, well let me know if you have thoughts. This thread is (hopefully) the final key to a paper I'm writing -- the main theorem will be that this process inputs an algebraic theory and outputs a polymorphic type theory.

But I'm getting the impression that formalizing polymorphism in general is not a simple task. From what I've seen in the literature so far, people usually just take the specific example of System F\mathbb{F}F and then augment that theory as needed; I haven't found much about polymorphic type theories in general.

Hey @Morgan Rogers, very nice! Here are some additional remarks from a paper that Mathieu Anel and I recently finished (over two years or so) that might answer some of your questions. https://arxiv.org/abs/2004.00731
As you note, ∫P\int P∫P is the small full subcategory of C^→\widehat{C}^\rightarrowC→ on the covering sieves, the codomain functor t:∫P→C^t : \int P \to \widehat{C}t:∫P→C factors through CCC and t:∫P→Ct : \int P \to Ct:∫P→C admits a section mmm (a right adjoint right inverse). If you replace ∫P\int P∫P by any small full subcategory of arrows W⊂C^→W \subset \widehat{C}^\toW⊂C→ satisfying the same conditions, you get what we call a pre-modulator (Def. 2.4.6). And of course every pre-modulator has a "plus-construction" given by the formula t!m∗t_! m_*t!​m∗​ that you mentioned.
Now a JJJ-sheaf is simply an XXX in C^\widehat{C}C that has the unique right lifting property against every arrow in ∫P\int P∫P. One can similarly define a "WWW-sheaf" for any pre-modulator, and the category of WWW-sheaves is a locally presentable, reflective and accessibly (for some κ\kappaκ) embedded subcategory of C^\widehat{C}C (however it's not a topos, but I'll get to that). An interesting result (follows from Th. 2.4.8 of the paper) is that the reflection from presheaves into WWW-sheaves can be calculated as the transfinite iteration of the plus-construction t!m∗t_! m_*t!​m∗​. In fact Th. 2.4.8 says more: there is a relative plus-construction for arrows, whose transfinite iteration is the unique factorisation of any fff in C^→\widehat{C}^\toC→ for the orthogonal factorisation system (⊥(W⊥),W⊥)({}^\bot(W^\bot), W^\bot)(⊥(W⊥),W⊥), and the plus-construction for objects of C^\widehat{C}C is just the relative plus-construction for arrows into the terminal object. Moreover, every accessible reflection (and every accessible orth. fact. system) of a locally presentable category can be calculated as the iteration of the plus-construction associated to some pre-modulator (Prop. 2.4.13).
Coming to topoi: A pre-modulator such that t:W→Ct : W \to Ct:W→C is a fibration is called a modulator (Def. 3.3.1) and a modulator such that each fibre of ttt is (finitely) co-filtered is called a lex modulator (Def. 3.4.1). The orthogonal factorisation system associated to a (lex) modulator is what's known as a (lex) modality. Every accessible (lex) modality is generated by a (lex) modulator. The reflection associated to a lex modality preserves all pullbacks (and hence all finite limits). In 1-topoi, every modality is lex but this is no longer true for ∞\infty∞-topoi. Finally, the plus construction associated to a lex modulator on an ∞\infty∞-topos converges in n+2n+2n+2 iterations on an nnn-truncated object of the ∞\infty∞-topos --- this implies that the plus construction for a lex modulator on a 1-topos converges in two iterations. The general theme of this "schmilblick" is that lex modulators are a correct generalisation of Grothendieck topologies from 1-topoi to ∞\infty∞-topoi.
The paper is a little dense but hopefully the previous remarks are enough of a foothold.

The composite of the Yoneda embedding and the category of elements el∘y:C→Cat\mathrm{el}\circ y: C\to \mathrm{Cat}el∘y:C→Cat is naturally isomorphic to the slice functor C/(−)C/(-)C/(−). Subfunctors of representables should presumably give subcategories of the slice categories.

Can you ask a question that's more specific than "how do I unpack all of this information canonically?"

The best questions in math are the yes-or-no questions, like "is 1 + 1 = 2?", since the answer is a truth value.

The second best questions are the ones that ask for an element of a set, like "what's 1+1?" or "how do I prove P?" where P is some true statement.

Often when you have a vaguer question you can find simpler sub-questions of the above two forms, which are a lot easier for people to sink their teeth into. This increases the chance of getting good answers.

Chaitanya Leena Subramaniam said:

On a related note I tried (and failed) yesterday to find an example of a locally presentable, locally cartesian closed 1-category that's not a quasitopos. Does anyone know of one?

This is a difficult problem with an interesting history, see Section 4 of Borceux and Pedicchio, A characterization of quasi-toposes. One example described therein, due to Adamek and Rosicky, is the category of sets equipped with a "loop-free" reflexive binary relation. Another example (Example C.4.2.4 in the Elephant) is the Ind-completion of the category of countable (= finite or countably infinite) sets.
